overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Comparing Slopes and Intercepts of Data from Experiments
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students engage in the statistical process with the Stroop Test. They formulate a statistical question based on the length of matching and non-matching word lists and the time to read them. Students collect data as they conduct the Stroop Test experiment and analyze the data using the best-fit equations. They interpret their results as they respond to their statistical question.

overview_item_data_items: I can write a linear function as a line of best fit for a set of data.
I can interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data.
I can interpret the slope and y-intercept of a linear function modeling a set of data.
Writing a statistical question is the first step of the statistical process. Your statistical question helps you to set up an experiment based on the explanatory and response variables.
You engage in steps two and three of the statistical process as you collect data from an experiment and analyze the data with a line of best fit.
You engage in the final step of the statistical process when you interpret your results based on your statistical question.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students analyze two lines on a graph within a context to notice patterns, ask questions, and interpret the meaning of slope and y-intercept.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Comparing Slopes and y-Intercepts of Lines of Best Fit
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students complete a Stroop Test experiment and analyze data as part of a statistical process.
Students compare the data from the Stroop Test and interpret the results as part of the statistical process.

overview_item_data_items: To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
